questions.title: Bubble Sort
questions.coreConcept: Repeatedly swap adjacent elements if they are in wrong order
approach: Compare adjacent elements
Swap if left > right
Repeat for each pass
After each pass, largest element bubbles up to end
commonPitfalls: Forgetting to optimize with sorted array check

questions.title: Two Sum
questions.coreConcept: Use hash map to store complement values
approach: Use hash map to store numbers and their indices
For each number, check if its complement exists
Return indices if complement found
commonPitfalls: Forgetting to check if complement exists before current index

questions.title: Binary Search
questions.coreConcept: Divide and conquer approach on sorted array
approach: Initialize left and right pointers
Find mid point
Compare target with mid
Update pointers accordingly
commonPitfalls: Infinite loop due to improper pointer updates

questions.title: Longest Palindromic Substring
questions.coreConcept: Expand around center approach or Dynamic Programming
approach: For each character, consider it as center
Expand around center for odd length palindromes
Expand around center for even length palindromes
Keep track of longest palindrome found

questions.title: Reverse Linked List
questions.coreConcept: Iterative or recursive reversal of linked list pointers
approach: Keep track of previous, current, and next nodes
Reverse links while traversing
Handle edge cases (empty list, single node)
commonPitfalls: Not saving next pointer before reversing

questions.title: Generate Parentheses
questions.coreConcept: Backtracking with valid parentheses rules
approach: Track open and closed parentheses count
Add open parenthesis if count < n
Add closed parenthesis if closed < open
Backtrack when invalid

questions.title: Number of 1 Bits
questions.coreConcept: Bit manipulation to count set bits
approach: Use n & (n-1) to clear least significant bit
Count number of operations needed
Alternative: Use built-in methods
commonPitfalls: Infinite loop with wrong bit manipulation

questions.title: Valid Parentheses
questions.coreConcept: Using stack to match parentheses pairs
approach: Push opening brackets onto stack
Pop and compare for closing brackets
Check if stack is empty at end
commonPitfalls: Not checking stack emptiness at end

questions.title: Merge k Sorted Lists
questions.coreConcept: Using min heap to merge multiple sorted lists
approach: Create min heap with first elements
Pop minimum element and add to result
Push next element from same list
Repeat until heap empty

questions.title: Power Of Two
questions.coreConcept:
A number n is a power of two if there exists an integer k such that 
ð‘›
=
2
ð‘˜
. In binary representation, this means that the number has exactly one 1 bit. For example:

1
 in binary is 0001

2
 in binary is 0010

4
 in binary is 0100
approach: Approach Steps Check for non-positive numbers: A power of two is always a positive integer. If n <= 0, return false.  Binary manipulation: Use bitwise operations to check if n is a power of two.  A power of two has exactly one 1 bit in its binary representation.  Using the property  ð‘› & ( ð‘› âˆ’ 1 ) :  If n is a power of two,  ð‘› & ( ð‘› âˆ’ 1 )  results in 0.  For example, if  ð‘› = 4 ,  ð‘› = 100 2  and  ð‘› âˆ’ 1 = 011 2 ; hence,  ð‘› & ( ð‘› âˆ’ 1 ) = 100 & 011 = 000 .
pitfalls: Common Pitfalls Zero and Negative Numbers: Ensure to handle cases where n is zero or negative. These should not be considered powers of two.  Bitwise Operators Precedence: Remember that bitwise operators have lower precedence than equality operators. Always use parentheses to ensure the correct order of operations.

questions.title: 3SUM
questions.coreConcept:
Taking 3 such values that they result in a target

Kinda straightforward, first of all sorting up the array cause it will have no such impact on answer but a surely will help in generating answer.

Core-> Firstly remember of 2SUM, a+b+c=target-> therefore a+b=target-c.... for interview

But here we can see that we can maximize or minimize the sum to achieve the target, in such a way that we take two pointers at i and j=i+1 and the last at last k=n-1
approach: min max and equality is the main thing to traverse through
Common things not to ignore are-> incrementing or continuing if we get same number again, cause it may give us duplicate values
Also j= i+1,  k=n-1 and while(j<k)

Two-pointer technique: Inside the main loop, the two-pointer technique runs in  ð‘‚ ( ð‘› )  time in the worst case, as both pointers traverse the entire array.  Combining these, the overall time complexity of the threeSum function is  ð‘‚ ( ð‘› log â¡ ð‘› + ð‘› 2 ) .
